Hey, Tesla Effect (excellent name, btw).

So - I have crummy news and not-so-rubbish news.  Crummy - I've been asked not to post a different version of the map.  The hope is that we can hold it back for a future release where there should be more content to go along with it.  So, the wiki image will have to wait for now.

Better news - I've been given the go ahead to talk about the map at least!  I don't actually know what form that should take... so... I'm gonna think about it over night.  Suggestions welcomed - maybe see if others on the boards have ideas too.  

Maybe a really tiny Q&A, or a role-played thread of correspondence between Euneterran cartographers, or something else entirely.  Suggestions *really* welcomed.  I don't just want to do a full info dump wall o'text. :/

(Just in case people coming to this have no idea what I'm talking about - this is in regards to the Shuriman tablet map that was shown in the Rek'Sai teaser site.)

Greetings Merchant of Glowing Algae Matter,

I am a merchant from southern Freljord trying to find his way to Shurima. Where the heck is the capital? What's the name of the capital? Is there sand people there or a bunch of desert nomads? Are there even sedetary towns? Where's Rek'Sai and her horde of Xer'Sai relative to all this?

Sorry, I got a bit too close to Sin's toxin.

Praise be to Bard. We should play some Riotball sometime.

Fair tidings, Master Jewfist,

How far you seek to travel!  I have some bad news for you in that such a thing as mighty as a 'capital' was wiped from knowledge of the Shuriman people, when the empire fell.  A people is only so populous as life giving water is able to sustain - and the desert is broad and deep.  Wells are rare and easily drained, so their cities are but hamlets and their villages frequently seasonal.  Travel without a guide is for those who tire of life.

The 'Sai, is for the most part, completely uninhabited - there is *no* trade to be done there.  It occupies the South of the desert 'empire' reaching from the endless mountain range, almost half way to where the city Shurima was (and they say, is again).  Coming from the Freljord as you are, I would say that should you find yourself on a parallel with that place - venture no further South.  It is weeks of the most hateful travel.

Sorry it is not happier news - there are still amazing prizes to be gathered for the courageous (and well prepared) merchant traveler in the stalls (and under the cloaks) of this brutal land.  Why, I recently acquired a map that no-one seems to want to talk to me about (( ;)  ))

With a plethora of thanks, 
Merchant of the Glowing-Life.

*The tired man enters the algae cartographer' s entourage. After dropping his runeforged void sword of infinite twerk looks at him straight in the eyes and asks...*

What about the borders?
I am not only talking about borders between factions - that probably will be rewritten totally - but also borders of the known world, sea too. Champions like Nami and Fizz home into the ocean from which we know nothing, and while that is partly ok ( the ocean is fascinating for that reasons ) we don' t know what the narrative team intends to do with those limits: will everything be discovered eventually? will be always left with a shade of mystery? and what about space, if there is any, since Bard existence opened some really interesting possibilities?

It' s a bit of a weird question, probably i did not even put it in the best terms... basically, what i am asking is if they have plans or decisions made for the large scale of the whole world. if they are interested on exposing them, obviously.

*sits in silence, only disturbed by the sword movements*

also, the sword thanks you for your time.

*The cartographer seems both disturbed and fascinated by the swords movement.  Long pauses are punctuated only be the sound of distant coughs from the neighboring rooms.  It's getting awkward.*

Sorry!  What was that?  Oh!  Borders.  Unfortunately, I don't have the answers you seek - I am a peculiarly specialized cartographer in that I've only ever had this one map.  I probably shouldn't even call myself a cartographer!  I...

*That sword.  What strange movements it makes...*

Sorry again.  Maps.  Yes.  No - I'm afraid I just don't know.  I know there are other cartographers hard at work even now, working to create a... mmm...  documentation, both written and drawn, of our macrocosm.  Some things are already known, of course, but others do indeed remain a mystery.  It is likely that this slow work will be shared with the greater scientific community in time.  

I have no doubt, however, that some corners will *remain* a mystery - here be dragons, indeed - because once we know everything - what cause have we left to explore?  Broad strokes; yes.  Dotted "i"s and crossed "t"s; only patchily.

No great answers there for you, I'm afraid - I'm really not specialized in those areas.  Ha!  Areas!  No-one laughs at cartographical jokes. 


(( Sorry, Decrit.  If you haven't guessed - I'm not a part of the narrative team, and while I got to make the Shurima map artifact, I don't have complete knowledge of the rest of Runeterra's map and cosmology.  There is work going on, though.))

Welcome, mysterious, mustachioed, stranger! 

Let me tell you about this wax-rubbing of an old Shuriman map I have here.

As you say, the map is round.  This, I believe, was a stylistic choice that [many ancient people used](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babylonian_Map_of_the_World) - long before realistic maps and realistic scales were used.  As such, the map is at least slightly symbolic.

Note too, the symbols around the edges.  On the left, what looks like the sun is drawn behind a mountain.  At the top of the picture, another sun is drawn - this time, above the mountain range.  Our image is missing what might have been shown on the right, but I have it on quite good authority that there would be another sun picture there.  It would probably have been drawn behind another mountain or range of hills.

In Shurima, as any visitor knows, the sun rises in the East, sweeps high across the sky on the North side, and then sets in the West.  If we take these symbols to represent dawn, noon, and the missing setting sun, then the drawing is orientated with North at the top.

I hope that helps with the beginnings of your studies.  I might draw your attention to some features that might reward greater study - particularly the interesting geological formations in the NE of the map, and the deep cuts in the SW of the map.  I'd love to hear your theories!

I, ahem, think you might want to see to your... animal... outside now.  Sir.
